passages.text: In the Q2 MOF Corporate Statistics, we expect capex growth to remain solid at \(+6.0\%\) yoy (Q1: \(+6.4\%\) ), and mark the fifth sequential growth at \(+0.9\%\) qoq (Q1: \(+1.6\%\) ). We also expect manufacturers' profits to decline by a wide margin.

The July nominal cash wage growth is likely to slow to \(+2.6\%\) yoy from \(+3.1\%\) in June, which was pushed up by summer bonuses. Basic wages likely to rise moderately, to \(+2.1\%\) yoy from \(+2.0\%\) in June.

The Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) plans to hold a joint plenary meeting of both Houses on September 2 to announce the results of its review of the Upper House election. The party will then begin procedures for holding an early party presidential election. According to some media, LDP Diet members and prefectural chapters who wish to request an election should submit their request by September 8.

The Tokyo new core CPI (excludes fresh food and energy) printed at \(+3.0\%\) yoy in August, decelerating from July, in line with the market forecast. This was mainly attributable to a slowdown in durable goods prices, reflecting the stronger yen in the past few months. Meanwhile, energy prices slowed due to the resumption of electricity and gas price control measures, pushing down the core CPI (excludes fresh food) by \(- 0.25\) pp. As a result, the core CPI inflation rate slowed to \(+2.5\%\) yoy (- 0.4 pp vs July), in line with the market forecast. We forecast the national core and new core CPI for August at \(+2.7\%\) yoy (- 0.4 pp) and \(+3.3\%\) yoy (- 0.1 pp), respectively.

Industrial production fell by \(- 1.6\%\) mom in July, turning down again after rising for the first time in three months in June by \(+2.1\%\) . The market forecast was for a decline of \(- 1.1\%\) . Art production fell sharply for the first time in three months, by \(- 6.7\%\) mom, pushing down overall production by \(- 0.87\) pp. The outlook for August called for a decline of \(- 1.7\%\) .

July retail sales growth was below the market forecast (+1.6%) at \(+0.3\%\) yoy (June: \(+1.9\%\) ). On a seasonally adjusted mom basis, retail sales fell by \(- 1.6\%\) (June: \(+0.9\%\) ), turning down again. Sales fell mom for all categories.
Upcoming Economic Indicators and Events

Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Bloomberg

Apr- Jun MOF Corporate Statistics: We expect recurring profits to decline yoy, led by the manufacturing sector. According to our equity strategy team's analysis, listed company results for April- June 2025 saw net profits decline by \(- 25\%\) yoy in the manufacturing sector, and by \(- 9\%\) yoy overall. We think it is likely that major Japanese automakers shouldered much of the tariff costs on auto exports to the US. In addition, the yen's appreciation of c.￥10 against the US dollar compared to April- June 2024 likely also contributed to lower earnings at exporters. We expect capex in the MOF Corporate Statistics to show robust growth, albeit slowing slightly

to \(+6.0\%\) yoy, from \(+6.4\%\) in January- March 2025. On a qoq basis, we expect capex to rise by \(+0.9\%\) (January- March \(+1.6\%\) ), marking the fifth consecutive quarter of growth. Real capex in the preliminary estimate for April- June GDP rose by \(+5.5\%\) qoq annualized. If capex in the NOPF Corporate Statistics comes in broadly in line with our forecast, revisions to capex in the second preliminary estimate for April- June GDP scheduled for release on September 8, are likely to be limited. While intensifying labor shortages are acting as a supply constraint and weighing on capex, corporate demand for investment remains strong, including for digitalization, efficiency improvements, and environmental measures, and capex continues on an upward trend.

July Wages: Nominal cash wage growth was \(+3.1\%\) yoy in June (revised upward from the preliminary reading of \(+2.5\%\) ). While basic wages saw a moderate increase of \(+2.0\%\) yoy, special wages, which included summer bonuses and accounted for over \(40\%\) of June wages, increased by \(+4.4\%\) , pushing up the overall print by \(+1.9\) pp. We expect basic wages to rise moderately by \(+2.1\%\) yoy in July as well, but with the contribution from special wages diminishing, we expect nominal cash wage growth to slow to \(+2.6\%\) yoy.

Presidential Election: The Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) plans to hold a joint plenary meeting of both Houses on September 2 to announce the results of its review of the Upper House election (Nikkei, August 26, 28). Secretary- General Hiroshi Moriyama has previously stated that he will explain his responsibility based on the election review, and we think attention will be focused on Mr. Moriyama's next move, as he has been a key supporter of Prime Minister Shigeru Ishida. Based on the election review report, the LDP will begin procedures for holding an early party presidential election. Such an election requires requests from a majority (172) of the total number of 295 LDP Diet members and 47 prefectural chapters. Diet members who wish to request an election must submit their request in writing to the LDP headquarters during a five- to seven- day confirmation period following the September 2 joint plenary meeting (prefectural chapters can submit their requests by mail). The timing of the decision on whether to hold an election is unclear, but according to some media (NHK, August 28, etc.), the result is expected to be announced on September 8. The LDP Election Committee has decided to announce the names of Diet members who request an election. If a majority of Diet members request an early election, and an election is to be held, the voting day is likely to be at the end of September or later.

The Tokyo new core CPI was \(+3.0\%\) yoy in August, decelerating - 0.1 pp from July, in line with the market forecast. While the growth rate of food prices, excluding fresh food, was unchanged as the deceleration in rice prices was offset by an acceleration in other items such as dairy products, durable goods prices declined, reflecting the stronger yen in the past few months, pushing down the new core CPI.

Private- sector services (excluding rent), which the Bank of Japan often refers to in its Outlook Reports, remained largely unchanged from July \((+3.5\%)\) at \(+3.4\%\) yoy (our estimate). On a mom basis, they rose \(+0.4\%\) , maintaining a growth rate of generally over \(+3\%\) in annualized terms since 2H2024. In August, in addition to higher dining out service prices, small price increases were seen in several items such as entertainment, communications, and construction- related services.

The global core CPI (excludes food other than alcohol and energy), which is not affected by food inflation, slowed to \(+1.5\%\) yoy, from \(+1.7\%\) in July. In addition to the aforementioned slowdown in durable goods prices, a slight deceleration in private- sector rent also contributed to the slowdown.

Meanwhile, energy price inflation decelerated significantly due to the resumption of electricity and gas price control measures, pushing down the core CPI by - 0.25 pp (this price control measure is expected to last for three months until October billing). As a result, the core CPI slowed by - 0.4 pp from July to \(+2.5\%\) , in line with the market forecast.
Excluding one- off special factors, the new core CPI (our estimate) came in at \(+3.2\%\) yoy in August, down - 0.1 pp from July.

Our August national core and new core CPI forecasts (data to be released on September 19), based on the August Tokyo CPI readings, are \(+2.7\%\) yoy (July: \(+3.1\%\) and \(+3.3\%\) \((+3.4\%)\) , respectively.

July production falls sharply, below market forecast: Industrial production fell by - \(1.6\%\) mom in July, turning down again after rising for the first time in three months in June by \(+2.1\%\) . The market forecast was for a decline of - \(1.1\%\) . Shipments declined for the second consecutive month, by - \(2.5\%\) (June: - \(0.8\%\) ). Inventories rose by \(+0.8\%\) (June: - \(0.3\%\) ), turning up for the first time in four months. The government maintained its overall assessment of industrial production as "see- sawing".
By sector, production declined in 9 of the 15 sectors and increased in 6 sectors. Auto production fell sharply for the first time in three months, by - \(6.7\%\) mom, pushing down

overall production by - 0.87 pp. Production also fell sharply for production machinery (- 6.2%; includes semiconductor production equipment) and general- purpose & business- oriented machinery (- 4.5%). The main sectors where production increased were chemicals (+3.2%), electrical machinery & information and communication electronics equipment (+1.8%), and electronic parts & devices (+2.4%).
The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry's (METI) bias- adjusted production outlook for August calls for a decline of - 1.7% mom.

July retail sales below market forecast: Retail sales growth in July was below the market forecast (+1.6%) at +0.3% yoy (June: +1.9%). On a seasonally adjusted mom basis, retail sales turned down, falling by - 1.6% (June: +0.9%).

By retail category (mom basis), sales declined for all categories. Sales of machinery & equipment, including home appliances, fell by - 4.2%, following a rise of +3.1% in June. Sales of textiles, apparel & accessories (- 0.7%; June: +2.2%) turned down for the first time in six months, and other retail sales, including drugstores, also turned down for the first time in five months, falling by - 1.8% mom. In June, sales rose for all categories other than fuel sales.

Looking at yoy sales by retail format, department store sales (existing store basis) continued to decline sharply, by - 6.1% (June: - 7.7%). A decline in duty- free sales (down - 36.3% yoy, according to Japan Department Store Association data) weighed on overall department store sales. Meanwhile, supermarket sales growth (existing store basis) remained strong, at +3.1% yoy (June: +3.1%).
Reference: Japan One Month Economic Calendar
